trans-unit.source: Creates and deletes Internet Information Services (IIS) 6.0 virtual roots.
The <xref:System.EnterpriseServices.Internal.IComSoapIISVRoot> interface defines methods for creating and deleting virtual roots in IIS 6.0.
This interface is implemented only by the IISVirtualRoot class and is used only within the .NET Framework infrastructure while creating a SOAP-enabled COM+ application virtual root.
<xref:System.EnterpriseServices.Internal.IComSoapIISVRoot> does not need to be implemented directly in your code.

Instead, use the <xref:System.EnterpriseServices.Internal.Publish> class, which implements the <xref:System.EnterpriseServices.Internal.IComSoapPublisher> interface that contains the <xref:System.EnterpriseServices.Internal.IComSoapPublisher.CreateVirtualRoot%2A> and <xref:System.EnterpriseServices.Internal.IComSoapPublisher.DeleteVirtualRoot%2A> methods.
However, <xref:System.EnterpriseServices.Internal.IComSoapPublisher.DeleteVirtualRoot%2A> is not fully implemented by <xref:System.EnterpriseServices.Internal.Publish>.
IISVirtualRoot is used internally by the .NET Framework.
You do not need to use it directly in your code.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.EnterpriseServices.Internal.IISVirtualRoot"></xref> class.
Creates an Internet Information Services (IIS) virtual root.
You do not need to call the Create method from your code.
Instead, use the <xref:System.EnterpriseServices.Internal.Publish.CreateVirtualRoot%2A> method.
A string with the value `"IIS://localhost/W3SVC/1/ROOT"` representing the root Web server.
The physical path of the virtual root, which corresponds to `PhysicalPath` from the <xref:System.EnterpriseServices.Internal.Publish.CreateVirtualRoot*> method.
The name of the virtual root, which corresponds to `VirtualRoot` from <xref:System.EnterpriseServices.Internal.Publish.CreateVirtualRoot*>.
A string to which an error message can be written.
Deletes an Internet Information Services (IIS) virtual root.
Even though it is public, the Delete method is not intended to be called directly.
Alternatively, there is the <xref:System.EnterpriseServices.Internal.Publish.DeleteVirtualRoot%2A> method.
However, this method is not fully implemented.
The root Web server, as specified by `RootWebServer` from the <xref:System.EnterpriseServices.Internal.IComSoapPublisher.DeleteVirtualRoot*> method.
The physical path of the virtual root.
The name of the virtual root.
A string to which an error message can be written.
